deployedGeneratedSources.name: #utility.yul

documentation.text:
@dev Emitted when the allowance of a `spender` for an `owner` is set by
 a call to {approve}. `value` is the new allowance.
@dev Emitted when tokens are minted and the total supply is increased.
@dev Emitted when tokens are burned and the total supply is reduced.
@dev Returns the name of the token.
@dev Returns the symbol of the token.
@dev Returns the number of decimals for the token.
@dev Returns the amount of tokens in existence.
@dev Returns the amount of tokens owned by `account`.

@dev Moves `amount` tokens from the caller's account to `to`.
 This is the public function, approval check not necssary. As the caller is the
 one transfering the tokens. Call the internal function _transfer.
 Returns a boolean value indicating whether the operation succeeded.

@dev Returns the remaining number of tokens that `spender` will be
 allowed to spend on behalf of `owner` through {transferFrom}. This is
 zero by default.
 This value changes when {approve} or {transferFrom} are called.

@dev Sets `amount` as the allowance of `spender` over the caller's tokens.
 Public function, should call to interal _approve
 Returns a boolean value indicating whether the operation succeeded.
 IMPORTANT: Beware that changing an allowance with this method brings the risk
 that someone may use both the old and the new allowance by unfortunate
 transaction ordering. One possible solution to mitigate this race
 condition is to first reduce the spender's allowance to 0 and set the
 desired value afterwards:
 https://github.com/ethereum/EIPs/issues/20#issuecomment-263524729

@dev Moves `amount` tokens from `from` to `to` using the
 allowance mechanism. `amount` is then deducted from the caller's
 allowance. This is the public function and should check approvals. Then call the
 internal function _transfer.
 Returns a boolean value indicating whether the operation succeeded.
from

@dev Mint `amount` tokens to the caller's account.
 This is the public function, Call the internal function _mint.
 Return a boolean value indicating whether the operation succeeded.
 IMPORTANT: In the real world, you would never allow users to simply mint tokens
 you would either require them to pay in some way for the tokens, or you would
 only allow minting from a trusted source/role/owner. For the purposes of this
 lesson, you will publically allow mints to anyone.

@dev Mint `amount` tokens to the a specified account `to`.
 This is the public function, Call the internal function _mint.
 Return a boolean value indicating whether the operation succeeded.
 IMPORTANT: In the real world, you would never allow users to simply mint tokens
 you would either require them to pay in some way for the tokens, or you would
 only allow minting from a trusted source/role/owner. For the purposes of this
 lesson, you will publically allow mints to anyone.

@dev Burn `amount` tokens from the caller's account.
 This reduces the total supply. This is the public function.
 Call the internal function _burn.
 Return a boolean value indicating whether the operation succeeded.

@dev Burn `amount` tokens held in a specified account.
 Ensure allowance is sufficient. This is the public function. Call the internal
 function _burn.
 Return a boolean value indicating whether the operation succeeded.

documentation.text:
@dev Moves `amount` tokens from the caller's account to `to`.
 Returns a boolean value indicating whether the operation succeeded.
 Emits a {Transfer} event.
 Requirements:
 - `from` cannot be the zero address.
 - `to` cannot be the zero address.
 - `from` must have a balance of at least `amount`.

typeDescriptions.typeString: literal_string "ERC20: approve from the zero address"

arguments.value: ERC20: approve from the zero address

argumentTypes.typeString: literal_string "ERC20: approve from the zero address"

typeDescriptions.typeString: literal_string "ERC20: approve to the zero address"

arguments.value: ERC20: approve to the zero address

argumentTypes.typeString: literal_string "ERC20: approve to the zero address"

documentation.text:
@dev Sets `amount` as the allowance of `spender` over the `owner` s tokens.
 Emits an {Approval} event.
 Requirements:
 - `owner` cannot be the zero address.
 - `spender` cannot be the zero address.

typeDescriptions.typeString: literal_string "ERC20: burn from the zero address"

arguments.value: ERC20: burn from the zero address

argumentTypes.typeString: literal_string "ERC20: burn from the zero address"

documentation.text:
@dev Burn `amount` tokens from the caller's account.
 This reduces the total supply. This is the internal function
 which should contain the logic for burning tokens.
 Return a boolean value indicating whether the operation succeeded.
 Emits a {Burn} event.
 Requirements:
 - `account` cannot be the zero address.
 - `account` must have at least `amount` tokens.

typeDescriptions.typeString: literal_string "ERC20: mint to the zero address"

arguments.value: ERC20: mint to the zero address

argumentTypes.typeString: literal_string "ERC20: mint to the zero address"

documentation.text:
@dev Mint `amount` tokens to the a specified account.
 This increases the total supply. This is the internal function
 which should contain the logic for minting tokens.
 Return a boolean value indicating whether the operation succeeded.
 Emits a {Mint} event.
 Requirements:
 - `account` cannot be the zero address.

Approval(address,address,uint256).details: Emitted when the allowance of a `spender` for an `owner` is set by a call to {approve}. `value` is the new allowance.

Burn(address,address,uint256).details: Emitted when tokens are burned and the total supply is reduced.

Mint(address,address,uint256).details: Emitted when tokens are minted and the total supply is increased.

Transfer(address,address,uint256).details: Emitted when `value` tokens are moved from one account (`from`) to another (`to`). Note that `value` may be zero.

allowance(address,address).details: Returns the remaining number of tokens that `spender` will be allowed to spend on behalf of `owner` through {transferFrom}. This is zero by default. This value changes when {approve} or {transferFrom} are called.

approve(address,uint256).details: Sets `amount` as the allowance of `spender` over the caller's tokens. Public function, should call to interal _approve Returns a boolean value indicating whether the operation succeeded. IMPORTANT: Beware that changing an allowance with this method brings the risk that someone may use both the old and the new allowance by unfortunate transaction ordering. One possible solution to mitigate this race condition is to first reduce the spender's allowance to 0 and set the desired value afterwards: https://github.com/ethereum/EIPs/issues/20#issuecomment-263524729

balanceOf(address).details: Returns the amount of tokens owned by `account`.

burn(uint256).details: Burn `amount` tokens from the caller's account. This reduces the total supply. This is the public function. Call the internal function _burn. Return a boolean value indicating whether the operation succeeded.

burnFrom(address,uint256).details: Burn `amount` tokens held in a specified account. Ensure allowance is sufficient. This is the public function. Call the internal function _burn. Return a boolean value indicating whether the operation succeeded.

decimals().details: Returns the number of decimals for the token.

mint(uint256).details: Mint `amount` tokens to the caller's account. This is the public function, Call the internal function _mint. Return a boolean value indicating whether the operation succeeded. IMPORTANT: In the real world, you would never allow users to simply mint tokens you would either require them to pay in some way for the tokens, or you would only allow minting from a trusted source/role/owner. For the purposes of this lesson, you will publically allow mints to anyone.

mintTo(address,uint256).details: Mint `amount` tokens to the a specified account `to`. This is the public function, Call the internal function _mint. Return a boolean value indicating whether the operation succeeded. IMPORTANT: In the real world, you would never allow users to simply mint tokens you would either require them to pay in some way for the tokens, or you would only allow minting from a trusted source/role/owner. For the purposes of this lesson, you will publically allow mints to anyone.

name().details: Returns the name of the token.

symbol().details: Returns the symbol of the token.

totalSupply().details: Returns the amount of tokens in existence.

transfer(address,uint256).details: Moves `amount` tokens from the caller's account to `to`. This is the public function, approval check not necssary. As the caller is the one transfering the tokens. Call the internal function _transfer. Returns a boolean value indicating whether the operation succeeded.

transferFrom(address,address,uint256).details: Moves `amount` tokens from `from` to `to` using the allowance mechanism. `amount` is then deducted from the caller's allowance. This is the public function and should check approvals. Then call the internal function _transfer. Returns a boolean value indicating whether the operation succeeded. from
